thread.title: Sunderland could not have signed Yann M'Vila and Jan Kirchhoff outside the EU
thread.title_full: Sunderland could not have signed Yann M'Vila and Jan Kirchhoff outside the EU

author: Steve Brown
title: Sunderland could not have signed Yann M'Vila and Jan Kirchhoff outside the EU

organizations.name: european union shares get sunderland afc

text:
Sunderland could not have signed Yann M'Vila and Jan Kirchhoff outside the EU 13:33, 24 Jun 2016 Sunderland may not have been able to land eight of their top stars had they tried to do so with Britain outside the European Union Shares Get Sunderland AFC news by email 2016 Sunderland AFC Fabio Borini (L) and Jan Kirchhoff during a Sunderland training session 
Sunderland would not have been able to sign Yann M’Vila, Jan Kirchhoff or Fabio Borini had Britain been outside the European Union when they came to the UK, according to research. 
The Black Cats would in such circumstances also have been unable to recruit Vito Mannone , Younes Kaboul and Patrick Van Aanholt, as well as Jeremain Lens and Ola Toivonen. 
Britain will leave the EU following Thursday’s historic referendum, which saw 52 per cent of voters opt for Brexit. 
What that specifically means for all concerned remains to be seen. 
The ability of British clubs to sign players from within the Eurozone aged 16 and 17 - currently enshrined by FIFA - may be revoked, though that would hand greater opportunity to homegrown youngsters. 
Yet as the pound loses value, transfer fees for foreign stars could rise and the freedom to sign them could become more difficult. 
EU passport holders are able to work in other EU countries without restriction. 
But crossing European borders requires footballers to obtain a work permit from the Home Office which is issued based on the number of international caps they have won over the previous 24 months, and on where their nation is ranked by FIFA. 
And following the decision to sever ties with Europe, a report has revealed that 108 current Premier League players lack the necessary requirements to have completed their transfers had they attempted to do so with Britain outside the union. 
That group includes some key figures - M’Vila, Kirchhoff, Borini, Mannone, Kaboul and Van Aanholt, none of whom have been regular internationals over the past two years - in Sunderland’s successful battle against relegation last season. 
Under-performing Lens and Toivonen would also have been unable to join the Black Cats. 
However, such players are not about to be booted out of British football, with rules not set to be implemented retrospectively. 
And experts believe players from EU countries will still be able to come to British clubs on the basis of a soon-to-be-contrived ‘favoured’ status. Sunderland transfer speculation - summer 2016
